SubTopics: Explain how an author develops the point of view of the narrator or speaker in a text.
Content: Which quotation from the passage shows Heidi's perspective on the place where she has decided to sleep?

A.Choice: “Heidi thrust in her bundle of clothes, as far back behind her grandfather's things as possible, ...” (paragraph 8)

B.Choice: “... near her grandfather's bed she saw a short ladder against the wall; up she climbed and found herself in the hay-loft.” (paragraph 10)

C.Choice: “... she called down to him, 'it's lovely, up here. Come up and see how lovely it is!'” (paragraph 11)

D.Choice: “'That is capital,' said her grandfather; 'now we must put on the sheet.'” (paragraph 15)

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: Which paragraph from the passage uses figurative language to develop Heidi's character?

A.Choice: paragraph 3

B.Choice: paragraph 5

C.Choice: paragraph 7

D.Choice: paragraph 11

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text based upon this determination.
Content: :ibox:The following problem has TWO parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Which statement describes a theme of the excerpt from Heidi?

A.Choice: Hard work brings great rewards.

B.Choice: Always make the best of a situation.

C.Choice: A great imagination can bring happiness.

D.Choice: Listening to your elders is the right thing to do.

Content: Which quotation from the passage supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “The old man turned and looked searchingly at the child, whose dark eyes were sparkling in delighted anticipation of what she was going to see inside.” (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: “Heidi did as she was told. The old man now opened the door and Heidi stepped inside after him; she found herself in a good-sized room, which covered the whole ground floor of the hut.” (paragraph 8)

C.Choice: “There lay a large heap of fresh, sweet-smelling hay, while through a round window in the wall she could see right down the valley.” (paragraph 10)

D.Choice: “It looked as tidy and comfortable a bed as you could wish for, and Heidi stood gazing thoughtfully at her handiwork.” (paragraph 16)

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: When Heidi's grandfather tells her she may sleep wherever she likes, she begins her search for a place. What can the reader infer about Heidi based on her reaction?

A.Choice: Heidi is happy because she enjoys sleeping in unfamiliar places.

B.Choice: Heidi is enthusiastic about the possibilities of her sleeping choices.

C.Choice: Heidi is tired from her journey and wants to go find somewhere to sleep quickly.

D.Choice: Heidi is resentful toward her grandfather because she does not have a bed to sleep in.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 6 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 14.

:ibox:“All right,” said the grandfather, and presently he went to the cupboard, and after r͟u͟m͟m͟a͟g͟i͟n͟g about inside for a few minutes he drew out a long, coarse piece of stuff, which was all he had to do duty for a sheet.
What is the meaning of r͟u͟m͟m͟a͟g͟i͟n͟g as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: organizing

B.Choice: reaching

C.Choice: searching

D.Choice: wandering

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text based upon this determination.
Content: Which sentence should be included in an accurate summary of “Rick Hires a Room on Mott Street”?

A.Choice: Rick has slept in boxes and wagons before.

B.Choice: Rick arrives at Mrs. Mooney's to talk to her about renting a room.

C.Choice: Mrs. Mooney informs Rick that she will not be able to fix up the room until tomorrow.

D.Choice: Mrs. Mooney and Rick decide that he will pay her 75 cents at the beginning of each week for rent.

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.
Content: :ibox:The following problem has TWO parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
What is a theme of the passage?

A.Choice: Hard work will pay off in getting things desired.

B.Choice: People can improve themselves through learning.

C.Choice: Well dressed people are treated better than others.

D.Choice: People should try to do the best with what they have.

Content: Which quotation helps develop the theme?

A.Choice: “It had once been covered with an oilcloth carpet, but this was now very ragged, and looked worse than none.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “In comparison with a box, or an empty wagon, even this little room seemed comfortable.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “'Well, as times is hard, and I can't afford to keep it empty, you may have it. When will you come?'” (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: “'Oh, I'm professional!' said Rick.” (paragraph 18)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: What does the phrase “increased favor” in paragraph 23 suggest about Mrs. Mooney's reaction to Rick's claim that he knows her son?

A.Choice: She is upset about the claim, so she views Rick poorly.

B.Choice: She is glad that he knows her son, so she views him positively.

C.Choice: She is suspicious about the claim, so she is unsure about Rick.

D.Choice: She is surprised that he knows her son, so she wants to know more.

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast texts in different forms or genres (e.g., stories and poems; historical novels and fantasy stories) in terms of their approaches to similar themes and topics.
Content: How do paragraph 8 from the excerpt from Heidi and paragraph 2 from “Rick Hires a Room on Mott Street” contribute to the overall development of each passage?

A.Choice: by including dialogue that propels the action

B.Choice: by showing how the setting will cause conflict in the passage

C.Choice: by introducing where the action from the passage will take place to establish the setting

D.Choice: by demonstrating the characters' problematic character traits that contribute to the theme

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast texts in different forms or genres (e.g., stories and poems; historical novels and fantasy stories) in terms of their approaches to similar themes and topics.
Content: Select two statements that show how Heidi's new home situation in the excerpt from Heidi is different from Rick's in “Rick Hires a Room onMott Street.”

A.Choice: Heidi is homeless prior to moving and Rick is not.

B.Choice: Heidi has her own room while Rick must share a room.

C.Choice: Heidi is initially upset about her new residence while Rick is happy.

D.Choice: Heidi is sent to live with family while Rick chooses where he will live.

E.Choice: Heidi shows a more positive attitude while Rick is more reserved about how he feels.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how a key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, and elaborated in a text (e.g., through examples or anecdotes).
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 3.
:ibox:“About 80 percent of the dogs and cats that are used in film are shelter rescues or shelter placements,” notes Marie Belew Wheatley, president and CEO of the American Humane Association (AHA).
What idea does the author introduce with the sentence?

A.Choice: Dogs and cats that live with people are too lazy to learn anything.

B.Choice: Production companies can return animals if they do not perform well.

C.Choice: Animals that make good actors are difficult for regular people to handle.

D.Choice: Dogs and cats with a variety of issues and experiences can be trained into actors.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Content: What is the author's purpose in the passage?

A.Choice: to explain the process of choosing and training film dogs

B.Choice: to inform readers that film dogs are mostly rescue dogs

C.Choice: to persuade readers to adopt dogs from rescue shelters

D.Choice: to contrast dogs that require training and those that do not

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, distinguishing claims that are supported by reasons and evidence from claims that are not.
Content: Read the claim made by Marie Belew Wheatley in paragraph 3.
:ibox:Even if prior owners had trouble handling them, trainers can work with most problem behaviors except biting.
Which TWO quotations support Wheatley's claim?

A.Choice: “At first, Shadow was anxious and insecure. De Cagny built up his confidence, little by little.” (paragraph 4)

B.Choice: “In contrast, Moose was extremely hyper, rebellious, and mischievous.” (paragraph 5)

C.Choice: “Many dogs love treats as a reward. Others work for praise, petting, or other attention.” (paragraph 7)

D.Choice: “Acting dogs learn lots of behaviors to look like they belong in a story.” (paragraph 9)

E.Choice: “What counts is how productions treat acting animals in real life.” (paragraph 11)

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 6 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: :ibox:The following problem has TWO parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Which word means the same as the word r͟e͟b͟e͟l͟l͟i͟o͟u͟s in paragraph 5?

A.Choice: disloyal

B.Choice: disobedient

C.Choice: disorderly

D.Choice: dissatisfied

Content: Which quotation from paragraphs 6-7 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “'... I could see that he wanted to fight, ...'” (paragraph 6)

B.Choice: “'He would get frustrated and eventually give up.'” (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: “Many dogs love treats...” (paragraph 7)

D.Choice: “... other dogs have favorite toys or stuffed animals.” (paragraph 7)

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which sentence states a central idea of the passage?

A.Choice: Rescue dogs are as intelligent as any specific breed.

B.Choice: Dogs receive excellent care while they are working on a set.

C.Choice: Production companies should be applauded for saving dogs.

D.Choice: Special trainers are required to train dogs for on-screen acting.

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, chapter, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the ideas.
Content: How does paragraph 8 contribute to the development of ideas in the passage?

A.Choice: It shows a problem and solution for acting dogs and their behaviors on set.

B.Choice: It supports a cause and effect relationship between the trainer's methods and the dog's behavior on set.

C.Choice: It describes the consequences for acting dogs not following commands on set.

D.Choice: It compares and contrasts the two acting dogs discussed by Mathilde de Cagny.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Content: :ibox:The following problem has TWO parts. First, answer Part A. Then, answer Part B.
Which states an idea supported by the author in the passage?

A.Choice: Acting dogs require too much maintenance.

B.Choice: Acting dogs are difficult to train on set.

C.Choice: Acting dogs respond well to their trainers.

D.Choice: Acting dogs create fear for viewers.

Content: Which quotation supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Not just any old dog can show up on a set and become a star.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “'It takes about four months, if you spend every day, to get a good trained dog,' ...” (paragraph 9)

C.Choice: “After reviewing scene details with trainers, many productions rehearse with a stuffed animal.” (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: “To reassure viewers, many film productions invite safety representatives of the AHA to visit their sets.” (paragraph 12)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 12.
:ibox:Following detailed guidelines, representatives check to make sure that animals have a͟d͟e͟q͟u͟a͟t͟e food and water.
What is the meaning of the word a͟d͟e͟q͟u͟a͟t͟e as it is used in the sentence?

A.Choice: appropriate

B.Choice: particular

C.Choice: special

D.Choice: sufficient

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which is an accurate summary of the passage?

A.Choice: Most dogs used in film are rescue dogs. Trainers make the job feel like a game to the dogs. The dogs learn a variety of behaviors for their roles. Sometimes a representative from the AHA monitors the care of the dogs.

B.Choice: It takes four months for dogs to become actors. Trainers can work with most problem behaviors except biting. Trainers make the job feel like a game to the dogs. AHA representatives will not let the dogs do anything dangerous.

C.Choice: Most dogs used in film are rescue dogs. Trainers can work with most problem behaviors except biting. It is helpful to think like a dog. It takes four months to train a film dog. Sometimes a representative from the AHA monitors the care of the dogs.

D.Choice: It takes four months for dogs to become actors. Most dogs used in film are rescue dogs. Many dogs love treats as rewards. If a dog whimpers on screen, the animal seems hurt or sad. AHA representatives ensure that the dogs are not too hot or too cold.

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: What is the meaning of the phrase p͟a͟s͟s͟e͟s͟ ͟m͟u͟s͟t͟e͟r as it is used in paragraph 13?

A.Choice: uses animals

B.Choice: gets approved

C.Choice: employs trainers

D.Choice: possesses guidelines
